Award.AwardTitle: Hands-on Plant Tissue Culture Workshop for High School and Community College Teachers to be held June 11, 2016 at the 2016 World Congress on In Vitro Biology, San Diego, California
Award.AbstractNarration:
A hands-on workshop in plant tissue culture will be held at the Society for In Vitro Biology (SIVB) 2016 World Congress in San Diego (CA) on June 11, 2016. This one-day workshop will provide thirty teachers from community colleges and high schools in California with the basics of plant cell/tissue culture without extensive lab equipment. A laboratory guide and resources will be provided to enable participants to set up appropriate laboratory course work in plant tissue culture at their home institutions. In addition, participants will be provided with a one-day pass to attend sessions on biotechnology and genome editing at the SIVB Congress on Sunday June 12. It is the hope that participants will be able to enlighten and ignite students' interest in the exciting scientific career opportunities of plant cell/tissue culture, and give them a greater understanding of plant biotechnology.

Discussions between community college and high school biotechnology instructors with industry representatives have focused on the benefits of including plant cell/tissue culture into the science curriculum. This workshop is the result of those discussions and will provide hands-on training and information on how to incorporate plant tissue culture into the classroom. Participants will construct "sterile hoods" and gain experience in sterile tissue culture techniques. They will also receive instruction on how to provide lessons and ideas for their curriculum. All workshop materials will be made available online to ensure the broadest dissemination. Availability of "sterile hood" kits for check-out to classrooms may be set-up via the Miramar Amgen Teacher Support Center portal.

Institution.Name: Society for In Vitro Biology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: SOCIETY FOR IN VITRO BIOLOGY, INCORPORATED

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this workshop was to inform and educate local instructors who train our workforce on the topic of plant cell/tissue culture and plant biotechnology - particularly those instructors who teach underrepresented students.

An all-day (8 hours) hands-on workshop on plant cell/tissue culture was provided for 27 Community College and High School instructors at the 2016 World Congress on In Vitro Biology held in San Diego, June 11, 2016.

Participants learned: general information about plant tissue culture: safety precautions and procedures;  information on MSDS; use of associated equipment; media preparations kitchen vs. lab methods; how to assemble “sterile hoods”;  prepare the work area; watched demos then performed disinfection and culture of several plant tissues; and basic concepts of sterile techniques. Particular instruction was provided for the culturing of plant meristems. Participants networked with local experts from academic and industrial laboratories and several vender representatives – all who served as instructional assistants.

Participants also received information on how these methods are used to produce food and plant products used by society, and the science that differentiates GMO and Non-GMO products. References provided for newer technologies used for genetic modification: Zinc-fingers, TALENS, CRISPR, ODN.

The post workshop survey indicated that 64% of participants teach plant science related topics, 24% teach biotechnology, and four workshop participants reported that they were unaware of plant tissue/culture methods were used in research or that careers existed in this field. All participants were excited to discover that plant tissue/cell culture is affordable and can be easily incorporated into their science curriculum as a hands-on activity. Workshop materials were new information to 96% of the participants.

Each workshop participant received a Basic Classroom Ready Kit from Kitchen Culture Kits Inc., to use in their own classroom. In addition several instructional kits, supplies and materials were donated by vendors and several items were raffled off at the end of the workshop:

 

  • Carolina Biological, “African Violet” kit
  • Caisson Labs, MS medium and vessels
  • KemTec, kits “Intro to Plant Cancer”, “Plant Cloning 1”, and “African Violet”;  
  • Microclone, kits “Seed Starter”, “Super Starter”, and “Tissue Culture”
  • Phytotechnology, kits “Fern Propagation” and “Sundew/Venus Fly Trap”
  • Plant Cell Technology, Plant Preservation Mixture (PPM)
  • Kitchen Culture Kits Inc. donated an additional “Basic Classroom Ready” kit.

 

Five participants donated their “Basic Classroom Ready” kits to workshop co-sponsor Southern California Biotechnology Center, to establish a classroom set of “sterile hoods” and equipment that can be borrowed by local San Diego teachers. The Salk Education Outreach Program is assisting with curriculum development and deployment.

Participants attended this workshop for their personal interest (64%), to investigate plant cell/tissue culture as a potential teaching topic (48%), and to increase their professional knowledge (48%).

Workshop participants said they would most likely contact the participating vendors (56%), workshop instructors (36%), and highlighted experts (28%) for information to further develop their curriculum.

Participants additionally reported that they would share what they have learned with their institutional departments (60%), county-wide peers (24%), at professional conferences (20%), and with the general community (20%).

A resource guide was distributed to the workshop participants on USB drives. This material is made available for all interested on the Society for In Vitro Biology (SIVB) home page listed under Resources, "Plant TC Workshop Materials": https://sivb.org/       

These workshop participants are instructors at Community College and High Schools. They provide education and training to the general public and our future workforce. These instructors often provide information to the general populations for their first, and sometimes only, exposure to science and technology. It is important to have a general population that understands the science and technology in their food and energy systems for the advancement and sustainability of all mankind.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2017
Modified by: Kim K Hanson

Particular instruction was provided for the culturing of plant meristems. Participants networked with local experts from academic and industrial laboratories and several vender representatives – all who served as instructional assistants. Participants also received information on how these methods are used to produce food and plant products used by society, and the science that differentiates GMO and Non-GMO products. All participants were excited to discover that plant tissue/cell culture is affordable and can be easily incorporated into their science curriculum as a hands-on activity. These instructors often provide information to the general populations for their first, and sometimes only, exposure to science and technology. It is important to have a general population that understands the science and technology in their food and energy systems for the advancement and sustainability of all mankind.
